discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Admins and Users too need a Teams Premium (users need it to be assigned a policy package): https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/teams-add-on-licensing/licensing-enhance-teams#which-users-should-be-assigned-teams-premium-licenses

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription and a Microsoft Teams deployment that contains the users shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You plan to use a custom policy package to contain a set of meeting policies, calling policies, and live event policies.

You need to ensure that Admin1 can create the custom policy package, and User1 and User2 can be assigned the package.

Which users require a Teams Premium license?

choices.D: From Permission policies in Team apps, create an app permission policy that blocks the Avatars app and assign the policy to User1.
choices.C: From Setup policies in Team apps, modify the SalesApps policy.
choices.B: From Manage users in Users, modify the settings of User1.
choices.A: From Manage apps in Teams apps, set the Avatars app status to Blocked.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that includes Microsoft Teams.

You have an app setup policy named SalesApps that installs the Avatars app for the users in your company's sales department.

You discover that a sales department user named User1 has an avatar that does NOT meet company standards.

You need to remove the avatar of User1. The solution must NOT affect any other sales department users.

What should you do from the Microsoft Teams admin center?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Need to modify from user settings , Manager users --- > Apps

Selected Answer: B
To remove the avatar of User1 without affecting other sales department users, you should modify the settings of User1 from the Manage users section in the Microsoft Teams admin center (Option B). This allows you to address the issue for the specific user without changing the app setup or permission policies for the entire department

Selected Answer: B
D block avatar app, B remoove avatar from user.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Teams deployment.

You have a meeting room that contains a Teams Rooms for Android device assigned to an account named Room1.

You deploy a Teams panel to the entrance of the meeting room and sign in the panel by using the Room1 account.

You need to ensure that attendees are notified when participants of the next meeting are waiting to use the room.

What should you configure from Device settings on the Teams panel?

You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.

You need to deploy the Hotline feature to a group of Teams devices.

What should you do?

choices.D: From the Microsoft Teams admin center, create a configuration profile for Teams Phone.
choices.B: From the Microsoft Teams admin center, create a configuration profile for Teams displays.

questions.question_text:
You have a Teams Phone deployment that uses Direct Routing on a single Session Border Controller (SBC).
Users report that outbound PSTN calls are failing, but inbound PSTN calls are successful.
When you review the SBC logs, you discover that Microsoft is responding to SIP option requests, but is NOT sending SIP option requests.
What is the cause of the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The issue you're describing is most likely caused by an external DNS entry missing from the FQDN of the SBC (Option C). When the external DNS entry is missing, Microsoft Teams cannot properly resolve the SBC's FQDN, which can lead to issues with SIP options and call routing

Selected Answer: C
If the SBC is disabled, how is it sending SIP option requests? However, a failure to send SIP option back to the SBC could be for lack of a (or incorrect) FQDN to send them to.

comments.content: Correct, in this case the incorrect configuration is likely FQDN related

discussion.content: If Microsoft is responding to SIP OPTIONS requests but not initiating them, it indicates that the connection from the SBC to Microsoft Teams is alive, but there may be a problem with how the SBC is configured to handle outbound calls.

comments.content: That link answers no calls being made but that is not the question. In the question, some calls are working while others are not. Further, the question focuses on MS not sending SIP options. This indicates network issues such as firewall, FDQN, etc.

choices.C: An external DNS entry is missing from the FQDN of the SBC.
choices.A: The online PSTN gateway is disabled.
choices.D: The phone numbers of the users are defined by running the New-csTeamsUnassignedNumberTreatment cmdlet.
